Answers.MP Summary: send a signal to a process
Top-3 Similar Questions: so_2970937: How to run a linux app in background process?
so_24843614: Execute process in background, without printing "Done", and get PID
Top-3 Scripts:
so_24843614: $ function x { for A in {1..100}; do echo "$A"; sleep 1s; done }
$ read pid < <(x & echo $!)
$ kill -s 0 "$pid" &>/dev/null && echo "Process active." || echo "Process died."
Process died.
$ read pid < <(x > /dev/null & echo $!)
$ kill -s 0 "$pid" &>/dev/null && echo "Process active." || echo "Process died."
Process active.

Explanations about Options.-s:
Specify the signal to be sent. The signal can be specified by using name or
 number. The behavior of signals is explained in signal(7) manual page.

Answers.MP Summary: screen manager with VT100/ANSI terminal emulation
Top-3 Similar Questions: so_17151141: Running Bash Script Without ending it on Exit

Explanations about Options.-r:
resumes a detached screen session. No other options (except combinations with -d/-D)
 may be specified, though an optional prefix of [pid.]tty.host may be needed to
 distinguish between multiple detached screen sessions. The second form is used to
 connect to another user's screen session which runs in multiuser mode. This indicates
 that screen should look for sessions in another user's directory. This requires
 setuid-root.
Explanations about Options.-d:
does not start screen, but detaches the elsewhere running screen session. It has the
 same effect as typing "C-a d" from screen's controlling terminal. -D is the
 equivalent to the power detach key. If no session can be detached, this option is
 ignored. In combination with the -r/-R option more powerful effects can be achieved:

Explanations about Options.-geometry:
This option specifies the preferred size and position of the VTxxx window; see
 X(7).
Explanations about Options.-n:
This option specifies the icon name for xterm's windows. It is shorthand for
 specifying the “iconName” resource. Note that this is not the same as the toolkit
 option -name. The default icon name is the application name.
